Award.AwardTitle: Improving Student Mastery of Welding Skills through Real-Time Assessment and Feedback
Award.AbstractNarration:
Welding technology is essential for producing many different types of products. As a result, highly skilled welders are critical in industries including manufacturing, construction, and energy. In particular, the rapid growth of manufacturing amplifies the need to prepare more welding technicians to meet industry demand. This project will expand the use of welding training systems to provide students with real-time feedback during training sessions. The welding trainer and virtual tracking system will capture and evaluate each action a welder makes to complete an assignment and will create a success score for the activity. The project will use this assessment to provide students with credit for existing skills, to create a student portfolio for employment, and to train incumbent employees or develop customized training profiles for specific workplaces. This assessment-driven approach is expected to contribute to the development of standardized welding practices. By engaging with precollege students interested in welding pathways and employer partners interested in providing students with experiential learning opportunities, the project also expects to strengthen partnerships with industry and high schools.

The goal of this project is to create a standardized welding pathway that can be scaled to other institutions and partnerships. Students will be able to develop their technical skills through efficient, industry-standard training. Performance data will be collected from professional welders in industry to construct a baseline model for student welding skills. Students’ actions during welding exercises will be captured using a welding trainer and virtual tracking system. The baseline model will be used to evaluate and automatically generate a formative assessment of student performance. The project will provide professional development opportunities for K-12 and community college instructors and will partner with Weld-Ed at Lorain Community College for additional professional development. A veteran outreach plan will expedite the assessment process to validate Prior Learning Assessment experiences for veterans and will map the current military training to formal welding education. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation’s economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction: 
Columbus State WeldTools is an educational platform developed by Columbus State Community College’s Welding Education Learning and Development Standardization program. The technology is an innovative combination of welding trainer and virtual tracking system technologies to capture, compare, and evaluate the actions of individual welders. The technology creates a database of Master Welding Profiles of skilled experts and employment partners. These profiles capture welding variables such as travel angle, travel speed, contact-to-work distance, wire feed speed, amperage, voltage, and shielding gas. Student work can then be compared to and evaluated against the expert profiles. This comparison can be done in real time during class or a training session. The technology allows the instructor and student to see exactly how closely their skills align to the work of a master-welder. 

The positive outcomes of this work include an advancement of the general knowledge in the field of welding and community benefit in the form of increased capacity for student’s learning and employment opportunities. An unexpected outcome was the identification of institutional barriers that technology in and of itself is unable to overcome.  

Outcomes: 
The outcomes of Columbus State’s work are aligned with three main goals of the grant: Creation of a standardized welding pathway using the technology, the creation of a professional development model for instructors using the technology, and veteran outreach plan that would use the technology to aid veterans in applying their learned skills to the requirements of the standardized pathway and business associated partners.  

Columbus State’s first objective was to develop a standardized welding pathway in Central Ohio using the technology.  This objective was achieved through implementation of the technology and the creation of a database of master welder profiles. The work on this pathway both advances knowledge of welding and provides community benefit.  

The database of profiles expands general knowledge by cataloging expert welding work. This, in turn, creates positive impacts for students, instructors, and industry partners. Students can use the technology to create a portfolio of work that demonstrates skills specific to in-demand welding careers with employment partners. Instructors can provide elevated evaluations based on detailed datasets and industry standards. Instructors can also use the data to create a standardized curriculum. Industry partners gain data tracking capabilities that allow them to benchmark and upskill their employees. 

The Community benefits because the technology and database are both shareable resources.  As more users provide data to the system, the capacity of the database grows. The technology is used by the National Center for Next Generation Manufacturing and the Research Experience for Teachers NSF HAMMER.  

Columbus State’ second objective was to develop an instructor professional development model to train K-12 and community college instructors on how to integrate the technology into their curricula. This was accomplished by the creation of the Welding Technical Guide for the technology. This guide can be distributed to schools and training facilities. 

The Welding Technical Guide provides directions and incentives to connect instructors, students, and employment partners in the professional development process. The guide serves as a key outreach tool for K-12 and community college instructors. In addition to the basics of integrating the equipment into their existing curriculum, the technical guide helps in finding community partners. The Guide provides a framework for developing classes that prepare students for specific community employment partners. 

Columbus State’s third objective was to create a veteran outreach plan and expedited assessment process to validate Prior Learning Assessment experiences of veterans, to map the current military training to formal welding education, and to assess the MTAG process using the technology.  Unfortunately, the project team was unable to fully achieve this objective due to difficulties in communication between the college and the military. The main outcome of the work conducted towards veteran outreach and expedited processes was the identification of this unforeseen obstacle. 

The technology is capable of mapping current military training and skills. This could be used to evaluate and create portfolios of work for individual veterans. These portfolios would be useful for veterans in both the classroom and with employment partners. The barrier to accomplishing this is the limited accessibility of the correct administrators, instructors, and officials in the military. It is simply unclear who to contact to implement the technology and program. While this is difficult to frame this as a positive outcome, this obstacle can easily be seen as an opportunity for future programs to develop an outreach initiative. 

Conclusion: 
The positive outcomes of the standardized welding pathway and professional development objectives are notable. While the results of the veteran outreach objective were disappointing, the recognition of the obstacles in military and veteran assessment initiatives that are unrelated to the efficacy of the technology is an important take away. 

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2024
Modified by: Scott Laslo
